dk.statsbiblioteket.util.reader
Class ReplaceFactory

java.lang.Object
  dk.statsbiblioteket.util.reader.ReplaceFactory

@QAInfo(level=NORMAL,
        state=IN_DEVELOPMENT,
        author="te")
public class ReplaceFactory
extends java.lang.Object

A factory for creating Text-oriented replacers. A replacer will be selected and instantiated based on the given rules.

It is highly recommended to use this factory instead of directly creating replacers, as it selects the optimal replacer based on the rules.

See Also:
CharArrayReplacer, CharReplacer, StringReplacer, ReplaceReader

Constructor Detail

ReplaceFactory

public ReplaceFactory(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> rules)
Creates a factory that generates a replacer for the given rules. Changes to the rules between calls to getReplacer() are not guaranteed to take effect: Create a new Factory instead.

After a factory for a given set of rules is created, getting a replacer for the rules is very cheap as internal mappings are shared between the replacer instances.

Parameters:
rules - what to replace in the form of target=>replacement pairs.
Method Detail

getReplacer

public ReplaceReader getReplacer()
Creates a new replacer which uses the rules given in the constructor. This is fast and with little memory-overhead. This is a recommended method for getting distinct replacers for the same rules.

Returns:
a replacer based on the rules given in the constructor.

getReplacer

public ReplaceReader getReplacer(java.io.Reader in)
Creates a new replacer which uses the rules given in the constructor. This is fast and with little memory-overhead. This is a recommended method for getting distinct replacers for the same rules.

Parameters:
in - the input character stream in which to replace substrings
Returns:
a replacer based on the rules given in the constructor.

getReplacer

public static ReplaceReader getReplacer(java.io.Reader in,
                                        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> rules)
Creates a replacer from the given rules reading character data from in.

Note that you can reuse the replace reader with the same rules by calling ReplaceReader.setSource(java.io.Reader).

The factory will detect the optimal strategy for character replacement based on rules and return a CharArrayReplacer, CharReplacer, or StringReplacer accordingly.

Parameters:
in - the input character stream in which to replace substrings
rules - what to replace in the form of target=>replacement pairs.
Returns:
a replacer made from the rules.

getReplacer

public static ReplaceReader getReplacer(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> rules)
Creates a replacer from the given rules with an empty input stream. You will need to set the data source of the returned reader by calling ReplaceReader.setSource(java.io.Reader).

Note that you can reuse the replace reader with the same rules by calling ReplaceReader.setSource(java.io.Reader).

The factory will detect the optimal strategy for character replacement based on rules and return a CharArrayReplacer, CharReplacer, or StringReplacer accordingly.

Parameters:
rules - what to replace in the form of target=>replacement pairs.
Returns:
a replacer made from the rules.

getReplacer

public static ReplaceReader getReplacer(java.io.Reader in,
                                        java.lang.String... rules)
Get a new ReplaceReader on in by dynamically building a rule map where rules[i] maps to rules[++i].

You can resue the returned reader by calling ReplaceReader.setSource(java.io.Reader)

Parameters:
in - the input character stream in which to replace substrings
rules - what to replace in the form of target=>replacement pairs.
Returns:
a replacer made from the rules
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if passed an uneven number of arguments

getReplacer

public static ReplaceReader getReplacer(java.lang.String... rules)
Get a new ReplaceReader with an empty input stream. The replacement rules are dynamically build by mapping rules[i] to rules[++i].

Before reading from the returned reader you must call ReplaceReader.setSource(java.io.Reader) on it to set the underlying stream to replace substrings from.

You can reuse the returned reader by calling ReplaceReader.setSource(java.io.Reader).

Parameters:
rules - what to replace in the form of target=>replacement pairs.
Returns:
a replacer made from the rules
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if passed an uneven number of arguments
